Item:  9.01 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:00 PM Concerning D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. Re: Violations of Public Contract Code Sections 4104 and 4106; Consideration of Hearing Officer’s Findings and Recommendations and Additional Evidence; Discussion and/or Action Regarding Imposition of Remedies as Allowed by Law (Public Contract Code Section 4110) and Contract
	 
	 
Per Board Resolution 2011-2012-15, Associate Superintendent Marcus Battle conducted a public hearing on December 2, 2011, to hear and consider evidence whether D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. violated the Subletting and Subcontracting Fair Practices Act (Public Contract Code Sections 4100 – 4114 (the “Act”)) in connection with the Yerba Buena High School Title IX modernization Project.  At the time of the hearing D.L. Falk asserted that it did not receive adequate notice of the hearing.
	 
Attached are the findings and recommendations of Marcus Battle.  As noted in Mr. Battle’s findings, the evidence supports that DL Falk was provided timely and adequate notice of the December 2, 2011, hearing.  Nevertheless, In light of DL Falk’s assertion that it not receive adequate notice, this matter has been agendized as a further public hearing by the Board so that the Board may consider Mr. Battle’s findings and recommendations as well as allow DL Falk an additional opportunity to present any additional information and evidence to the Board for its consideration.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:    
That the Board consider any additional information presented by DL Falk at the time of the hearing, and thereafter adopt the findings and recommendations as presented.

SUBJECT:
Educare of California at Silicon Valley Presentation
	 
Educare of California at Silicon Valley (ECSV) is a unique partnership of many organizations and agencies throughout the county that have been working together for the past two years in the planning process to make Educare a reality in our county.  ECSV is a national model for early childhood education that will serve as an important lever to inform best practices and policy reform at the state and federal level.  The program in Silicon Valley will eventually serve 200 children in the Santee neighborhood.  As East Side Union High School District offers infant and toddler care through Cal-SAFE funding to pregnant and parenting teens, under discussion is the transfer of 24 of these spaces to the ECSV Program in Fall 2014.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  11.05
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation/Report Regarding the Architectural Window Testing at Evergreen Valley High School
			 
On August 17, 2011 a windowpane some 15 feet above the NE corner entrance to the gym at Evergreen Valley High School became dislodged and fell to the ground, sheering off the door handle directly beneath it.  Thankfully, there were no injuries to staff or students. This was the second failure reported in the same bank of windows, the other coming in 2008.
			 
As a result of this second failure, the District judged that this may not be an isolated incident and promptly implemented precautionary safety measures while evaluating the condition of the windows on the rest of the campus. These safety measures included:
Preliminary inspection of all similar windows,
Cordoning off affected areas,
Securing windows in frames using strong adhesive tape,
Building plywood breezeways over all entrances in affected areas, and
Notifying all parties with an interest in the site.
At the same time, the District engaged the services of Architectural Testing, Inc., whose job it has been to determine the extent of the issue, provide an analysis of the cause, and provide recommendations on the best method(s) to address the repair and/or replacement of all affected windows.
			 
A forensic study was conducted by Architectural Testing (Report attached) and it was determined that:
Some 241 windows are impacted,
Failure occurred only in windows using mechanical controls for opening and closing,
Failure occurred through delamination (unexpected separation) of the 2 panes in dual pane units; the primary cause of which is likely the use of dual pane glass units that were not certified for this use, and
Repair will need to be made through removal all affected dual pane units and replacement with dual pane units specified and certified for this type of use.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  11.06
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and in Consultation with SGI
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Repair/Replacement of Defective Windows at Evergreen Valley High School
			 
			 
On August 17, 2011 a windowpane some 15 feet above the NE corner entrance to the gym at Evergreen Valley High School became dislodged and fell to the ground. The District judged that this was not an isolated incident and in addition to implemented precautionary safety measures, retained the services of Architectural Testing, Inc. to determine the extent of the issue, provide an analysis of the cause, and provide recommendations on the best method(s) to address the repair and/or replacement of all affected windows. 
			 
Recommendations cite that any repair or replacement will require new dual pane window units of the type specified and certified for this use. Administration has directed staff to put in motion plans to proceed with this work. In view of the fact that affected windows are disbursed across the Evergreen Valley High School campus, staff has recommended that the project be completed during the summer of 2012 – when there is a minimum of competing activity on site – and that the design-build delivery method be used to bring economies of time and money to the project. 
			 
The primary objectives for the project are 1) installation of windows or window systems that meet or exceed the originally designed specifications for the affected windows, 2) completion of the project prior to the start of classes in the Fall of 2012, and 3) fixed price, established by the District in its Request for Proposals. 
			 
The recommendation of Architectural Testing points to at least 2 means though which the end goal of replacement could be achieved. At least one of those means would require jurisdictional reviews that could potentially interrupt a summer schedule. Furthermore, lead time for delivery of suitable glass is projected to be 60+/- days, meaning that project award should be made at the March meeting of the Board of Trustees. Finally, the traditional “design-bid-build” methodology would burden the project schedule with two procurement phases – one for design and one for construction – that together would make the summer schedule infeasible.
			 
It is recommended by staff that the project objectives, scope, schedule, and project budget be provided by the District in a Request for Proposals from prospective design-build teams (made up of contractors & architects or engineers) and that these teams provide proposals outlining their approach and schedule that will meet the District’s objectives for this project.
			 
Following is a summary of the anticipated project:
			 
General Scope is: removal, repair, and reinstallation (or) replacement of 241 dual pane windows from all impacted areas on the Evergreen Valley High School campus. New windows will be inspected and certified to meet or exceed originally designed specifications or current applicable code, whichever is deemed more rigorous.
			 
Preliminary Schedule is:
Procurement process for design-build teams – January 20- March 1, 2012
Board Recommendation of award – March Board Meeting (March 15, 2012)
Selected team orders replacement window units – April 2, 2012
Commencement of removal and repair or replacement (tbd) – May 29, 2012
Project completed, inspected, certified ready for occupancy – August 3, 2012
Project closed-out and filings completed by September 28, 2012
Project Budget is:
Project hard cost budget                 $203,000
Project soft cost & contingency         $53,000
Total Project Budget*                       $256,000
*inclusive of hard & soft costs, plus contingency 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$256,000.00
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
School Facilities Fund
			 
RECOMMENDATION: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and direct staff to proceed with the replacement of defective windows at the Evergreen Valley High School as soon as possible, using the design-build approach as outlined, with an overall project budget not to exceed $256,000, and funding directed from Fund 35.

Item:  11.09
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
CALIFORNIA CANCER RESEARCH ACT
Resolution #2011/2012-17
	 
	 
WHEREAS, the California Cancer Research Act is a state initiative which if passed by voters in June 2012 would raise the state’s tobacco tax by $1.00 per pack of cigarettes; and
	 
WHEREAS, more than 332,000 California high school students are current smokers, 36,900 California youth start smoking every year and 3,383,000 California adults are current smokers; and
	 
WHEREAS, according to the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, the $1 tax increase alone would prevent 228,000 children from becoming smokers in adulthood and more than 118,000 adult smokers in California would quit smoking; and
	 
WHEREAS, the California Cancer Research Act would provide more than $156 million annually to the state’s existing tobacco control programs to prevent and reduce the use of tobacco; and 
	 
WHEREAS, the California Department of Education would receive $31.2 million for school-based programs to reduce youth smoking; and 
	 
WHEREAS, by providing the funding we need to keep California’s anti-smoking programs strong, we can keep our kids from smoking and give smokers the help they need to quit; and
	 
WHEREAS, the California Cancer Research Act would provide $23 million annually for law enforcement efforts to reduce illegal sales of tobacco products to minors, and other anti-tobacco law enforcement; and
	 
WHEREAS, cigarette smoking and other uses of tobacco remain the leading causes of cancer, heart disease and stroke, and lung disease in California; and
	 
WHEREAS, despite continuing advancements in medical treatment and prevention, cancer remains a leading cause of death in California, with more than 140,000 Californians diagnosed with cancer every year; and
	 
WHEREAS, the California Cancer Research Act would provide nearly $600 million annually to fund research and make important advances in the prevention, detection, treatment, causes and cures for  cancer, lung disease, heart disease and stroke, and other tobacco-related illnesses; and 
	 
WHEREAS, the California Cancer Research Act will result in $5.1 billion in long-term health savings from reduced smoking. 
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the EAST Side Union High School District does hereby support the California Cancer Research Act of 2012, which will reduce smoking, especially among children and fund critical research to prevent and treat cancer, heart disease and stroke, lung disease and other tobacco-related illnesses. 
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 19th day of January, 2012, by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.

SUBJECT:
Receive the Fourth Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering October 1st  through December 31, 2011 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CASHEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from October 1, 2011 through December 31, 2011.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation

Attached is a revised resolution for the issuance of a fourth issue of general obligation bonds by the East Side Union High School District, which is a part of the $349 million General Obligation Bonds that was authorized by the voters at the February 5, 2008 election.
